publisher: Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences
abstract:
<jats:title>Significance</jats:title>
          <jats:p>
            Over 50 years ago, Dan Janzen proposed an integrative framework relating latitudinal differences in climate variability to elevational trends in species diversity. We show that tropical species in three independent insect clades have (
            <jats:italic>i</jats:italic>
            ) narrower thermal breadths, (
            <jats:italic>ii</jats:italic>
            ) decreased dispersal and higher population structure, and (
            <jats:italic>iii</jats:italic>
            ) higher cryptic diversity and speciation rates. This research tests all of the key predictions of Janzen’s hypothesis in related taxa. Our work advances the understanding of how climate variability shapes global diversity patterns, moving beyond simple correlations, to mechanistic links between climate, local adaptation, dispersal, and montane species richness.
          </jats:p>
title: Narrow thermal tolerance and low dispersal drive higher speciation in tropical mountains
